senses.de: To give official permission for something to happen, or to give someone the power to do something.
senses.ex: The city council has authorized the construction of new apartments.

Tips.title: Official Permission
Tips.description: Used when someone with authority allows an activity or process; implies legal or formal approval.
Tips.example: The school board authorized the new curriculum.

Tips.title: Legal Power
Tips.description: 'Authorize' often relates to laws or regulations giving power to act or proceed.
Tips.example: The government authorized the emergency use of the vaccine.

Tips.title: Not Delegating
Tips.description: Authorizing doesn't necessarily mean delegating the task; it can simply allow it to happen.
Tips.example: She authorized the sale without managing it herself.

senses.de: To officially allow someone to act for you, especially by writing a letter or a contract.
senses.ex: I authorize you to act on my behalf.

Tips.title: Acting Permission
Tips.description: When you authorize someone, you're giving them legal or formal consent to do something for you.
Tips.example: He authorized his lawyer to negotiate on his behalf.

Tips.title: Deputize Others
Tips.description: 'Authorize' implies empowering someone to act as your representative or agent.
Tips.example: She authorized her assistant to sign checks.

Tips.title: Written Confirmation
Tips.description: Authorizing often involves official documentation, like a letter or email to confirm.
Tips.example: They received a written notice authorizing them to proceed.

senses.ex: The bank has authorized the payment.

Tips.title: Financial Approval
Tips.description: Specific to money, it means officially approving a transaction or withdrawal.
Tips.example: The manager authorized the refund to the customer's credit card.

Tips.title: Transaction Security
Tips.description: In finance, authorization is a security measure to prevent fraud or misuse of funds.
Tips.example: The payment system authorized the charge after verifying the account details.

Accredit.wordDefinition:
To accredit means to give official recognition or approval to someone or something, usually through a formal process. For example, a university may accredit a college program to ensure that it meets specific standards.

Accredit is typically used in the context of official recognition or approval, while authorize is used in the context of giving permission or approval for something to happen.

Approve.wordDefinition:
Approve means to give permission or support to something. For example, a teacher might approve a student's request to take a day off from school for a family event.

In simpler terms, approve means saying yes to something, while authorize means giving someone the power to do something or giving official permission for something.

Empower.wordDefinition:
Empower means to give someone the power or ability to do something.

It is used when someone needs to feel confident in their abilities to carry out a task. For example, a teacher can empower their students by giving them the tools and knowledge they need to succeed in their academic pursuits.

Authorize is used when someone needs official permission to do something, while empower is used when someone needs the power or confidence to do something.

Endorse.wordDefinition:
Endorse means to express support or approval for someone or something. For example, a celebrity might endorse a product by appearing in an advertisement for it.

So basically, authorize is about giving permission or power, while endorse is about expressing support or approval. Both words are applicable in different situations depending on what is being referred to.

License.wordDefinition:
License means to grant official permission to do something or use something. For example, a driver's license is an official document allowing someone to legally drive a vehicle.

Authorize means giving permission for something to happen, while license means granting official permission to do something or use something.

Permit.wordDefinition:
The words authorize and permit both mean to give someone the go-ahead or approval to do something.

Permit is used when the person or organization giving permission doesn't necessarily have the power or authority, but they allow it anyway.

For example, a city might issue a permit for a construction project, meaning they allow it to happen even though they don't necessarily have control over the project itself.

In summary: Authorize means to give permission because you have the power or authority to do so, while permit means to allow something to happen even if you don't necessarily have complete control over it.

Ratify.wordDefinition:
Ratify means to approve or confirm something, usually by an official group or organization. For example, a government might ratify a treaty that was negotiated with another country.

The main difference between these words is that authorize is more about giving permission or authority for someone to take an action, while ratify is more about confirming or approving a decision that has already been made.

Sanction.wordDefinition:
However, authorize is usually used when someone grants permission or power to another person or entity to do something, while sanction is used when someone imposes a penalty or consequence due to someone else's actions.

A school might sanction a student for cheating on a test, meaning they impose a punishment or consequence for breaking the rules.

To authorize means to give permission or power to do something, while to sanction means to impose a penalty or consequence for actions taken.

Validate.wordDefinition:
Validate means to confirm or prove that something is true or accurate. For example, a doctor may validate a patient's diagnosis by conducting tests or a website may validate a user's login credentials before allowing access.

Authorize is applicable when someone needs permission to do something, while validate is applicable when checking the truth or accuracy of something.
